description:
Marmota marmota marmota, commonly known as the Alpine marmot, is a subspecies of the marmot family that inhabits the high-altitude regions of the European Alps. These large, ground-dwelling rodents are characterized by their distinctive reddish-brown fur, rounded body shape, and large bushy tails.

The Alpine marmot is a social animal, living in extended family groups that typically consist of a dominant breeding pair and their offspring from previous years. These groups establish complex burrow systems, which serve as their primary shelter and nesting sites. During the winter months, the marmots undergo a state of deep hibernation, relying on stored body fat to survive the harsh alpine conditions.

Adaptations of the Alpine marmot include a robust skeletal structure, thick fur, and the ability to efficiently regulate their body temperature. They are well-suited to the challenging alpine environment, with their strong limbs and sharp claws allowing them to navigate the rocky terrain and burrow effectively.

As a keystone species in the alpine ecosystem, the Alpine marmot plays a crucial role in maintaining the balance of the fragile high-altitude communities. Their presence is an indicator of the overall health and biodiversity of the alpine regions they inhabit.
